dt.t: her voice had an {wi}edge{/wi} to it

dt: {bc}keenness or intensity of desire or enjoyment
{bc}the line where an object or area begins or ends {bc}{sx|border||}
{bc}the narrow part adjacent to a border
{bc}a point near the beginning or the end
{bc}a line or line segment that is the intersection of two plane faces (as of a pyramid) or of two planes

et: Middle English {it}egge,{/it} going back to Old English {it}ecg{/it} "cutting side of a blade, border," going back to Germanic {it}*agjō{/it} "cutting side of a blade" (whence also Old Frisian {it}eg{/it} "cutting side of a blade, sword," Old Saxon {it}eggia,{/it} Old High German {it}egga, ekka{/it} "cutting side of a blade, border, point, corner," Old Norse {it}egg{/it} "cutting side of a blade"), feminine noun derivative from Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱ-{/it} "sharp, pointed," whence also Latin {it}aciēs{/it} "sharp part of a weapon"

The base {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱ-{/it} "sharp, pointed" was productive of a large number of suffixed derivatives in the Indo-European daughter languages. Latin had a verbal base deriving from {it}h{inf}2{/inf}eḱ-eh{inf}1{/inf}-{/it} "to be sharp" (see {et_link|acetic acid|acetic acid}, {et_link|acid:2|acid:2}) and a presumed adjectival stem {it}*acū-{/it} "sharp" (see {et_link|acute|acute}). An apparently isolated derivative is Greek {it}akmē{/it}́ "highest point" (see {et_link|acme|acme}). For the derivative {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱ-r-/h{inf}2{/inf}oḱ-r-,{/it} with outcomes in Greek, Latin, and other languages, see {et_link|acro-|acr-}, {et_link|mediocre|mediocre}. See also {et_link|awn|awn}, {et_link|ear:2|ear:2}.
shortdef: the cutting side of a blade

dt: {bc}to incline (a ski) sideways so that one edge cuts into the snow

et: Middle English {it}eggen{/it} "to set (the teeth) on edge," derivative of {it}egge{/it} {et_link|edge:1|edge:1}
shortdef: to be on an edge of

shortdef: a suburb that has developed its own political, economic, and commercial base independent of the central city

dt: {bc}the effect of an abrupt transition between two quite different adjoining ecological communities on the numbers and kinds of organisms in the marginal habitat

shortdef: the effect of an abrupt transition between two quite different adjoining ecological communities on the numbers and kinds of organisms in the marginal habitat

dt: {bc}to slowly become more successful, popular, etc., than (someone or something)

dt.t: The company is gradually {it}edging out{/it} the competition.
Efficiency has {it}edged out{/it} price as the top reason people give for buying the car.

shortdef: to slowly become more successful, popular, etc., than (someone or something)

dt: {bc}the newest and most advanced part or position especially in technology {bc}the extreme cutting edge

dt.t: So the first thing you learn about the Internet from studying America's Most Admired Companies is that you don't have to be on the {wi}bleeding edge{/wi} of the Web to be admired.

shortdef: the newest and most advanced part or position especially in technology : the extreme cutting edge
the foremost part or place : vanguard
